info.game_comments:
Mary Hirschfeld game 5.
Karl Coryat game 1.

(2, 1).clue: Marsh's Library in this country was founded c. 1702 by the Archbishop of Dublin

(3, 1).clue: In 1991 this telephone company launched its Friends & Family promotion

(4, 1).clue: This leader of the Green Mountain Boys did not live to see Vermont become a state

(5, 1).clue: It looks like a sweet potato, but it isn't even a distant relative

(6, 1).clue: You could say this comedy "ends well" -- Helena finally wins the love of her husband Bertram

(2, 2).clue: Architect Gordon Bunshaft designed this presidential library in Austin, Texas

(3, 2).clue: As of July 1, 1968 you could dial this 3-digit number in New York City & get the police

(4, 2).clue: This founding prophet of Mormonism was born in Sharon, Vermont in 1805

(5, 2).clue: It's a kind of striped mussel as well as a striped equine

(6, 2).clue: Though this comedy has Verona in its title, it ends in a forest on the frontiers of Mantua

(2, 3).clue: Sterling Memorial Library in New Haven, Connecticut houses the archives of this university

(3, 3).clue: On Oct. 30, 1938 phone traffic peaked in cities all over America as people discussed this broadcast

(4, 3).clue: This plow inventor was a Vermont blacksmith before moving to Grand Detour, Illinois

(5, 3).clue: Despite its bulk, this wild ox found in Tibet is an excellent swimmer

(6, 3).clue: Near the end of "Henry VIII", this princess is described as "a most unspotted lily", who will die a virgin

(2, 4).clue: Salinas, California, has a public library named for this novelist

(3, 4).clue: In 1980 Dial-It National Sports became the first service on this new area code

(4, 4).clue: George Franklin Edmunds wrote most of this antitrust act of 1890

(5, 4).clue: Some of these are produced by bremsstrahlung, from the German for "breaking radiation"

(6, 4).clue: Puck's last speech in this play begins, "If we shadows have offended, think but this--and all is mended"

(2, 5).clue: In 1602 this university's library reopened after restoration work by Sir Thomas Bodley

(3, 5).clue: In 1880 he invented the photophone, a device that sent messages through the air on beams of light

(4, 5).clue: At age 15 this future New York Tribune editor was apprenticed to a printer in East Poultney

(5, 5).clue: This Saint Francis was the "Apostle of the Indies"

(6, 5).clue: In the last scene of this comedy, Petruchio wins a bet that he has the most obedient wife

(1, 1).clue: In 1751, with Benjamin Franklin's help, the 1st hospital in the U.S. was founded in this city

(2, 1).clue: Of the 31 pilgrims in this Chaucer work, only 23 tell their stories

(3, 1).clue: Large aboriginal populations live in this country's states of Queensland & New South Wales

(4, 1).clue: The juice of one of these citrus fruits makes a Whiskey Sour sour

(5, 1).clue: In 1936, in defiance of the Treaty of Versailles, this country began remilitarizing the Rhineland

(6, 1).clue: He recorded "Gone At Last" with Phoebe Snow, not Art Garfunkel

(1, 2).clue: In 1867 Thomas Allbutt invented one of these instruments which took 5 minutes to register instead of 20

(2, 2).clue: This Longfellow poem was suggested by a smithy under a chestnut tree in Cambridge, Massachusetts

(3, 2).clue: Administrative units in this country include Giza, Aswan & Suez

(4, 2).clue: This pomegranate syrup turns a Pink Lady pink

(5, 2).clue: This longtime anchor of the CBS Evening News became a UPI correspondent in 1939

(6, 2).clue: She sang "Better Be Good To Me" in 1984, a few years after she broke up with Ike

(1, 3).clue: Dutch physician Willem Kolff developed the 1st of these kidney machines that cleanse the blood

(2, 3).clue: Oliver Wendell Holmes wrote of this ship, "Oh better that her shattered hulk should sink beneath the wave"

(3, 3).clue: This longest river on the Iberian Peninsula is also known as the Tajo

(4, 3).clue: A teaspoon of creme de cassis is added to this to make a Kir

(5, 3).clue: Helen Keller brought the first of these Japanese dogs to the United States in 1937

(6, 3).clue: In "Take Me Home, Country Roads", John Denver sang, "Almost heaven," this state

(1, 4).clue: In 1906 August von Wassermann developed a well-known test for this sexually transmitted disease

(2, 4).clue: His "When the Frost is on the Punkin" was written for a series in the Indianapolis Journal

(3, 4).clue: Cabinda, an area of this former Portuguese colony, is separated from the rest of it by Zaire

(4, 4).clue: A basic Gin Rickey is gin, lime & this non-potent potable

(5, 4).clue: He was appointed conductor of the Boston Pops in 1930

(6, 4).clue: Alan, Merrill & Wayne, 3 of these Utah brothers, co-wrote their own 1972 hit "Crazy Horses"

(1, 5).clue: In 1982 William DeVries performed the 1st permanent artificial heart transplant on this man

(2, 5).clue: He was descended from an Abyssinian prince, Peter the Great's godson

(3, 5).clue: The Indus River provides the western border of this desert also known as the Great Indian Desert

(4, 5).clue: Using Scotch whisky turns a Manhattan into this drink

(5, 5).clue: This author of "Anne of Green Gables" was awarded the Order of the British Empire in 1935

(6, 5).clue: This singer's 1970 hit "I'll Never Fall In Love Again" was from the Broadway musical "Promises, Promises"

(0, 0).clue: On May 29, 1765 Patrick Henry's Stamp Act protest was interrupted with this one word
